title: When do you feel sleepy?
intro: Alice and Neil discuss circadian rhythms – the so-called body clock that influences an organism's daily cycle of physical, mental and behavioural changes – And what shift workers can do to help.
this_week_question: What does the word 'circadian' mean? Is it…
You'll hear the answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: a cycle that tells our bodies among other things when to sleep, get up, and eat
disruption of our circadian rhythms caused by high-speed travel across different time zones, which can cause tiredness and sleep problems
move back and forth in a regular rhythm
work that takes place outside the traditional 9 to 5 day

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. And I feel terrible!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: You look terrible, Neil – if you don't mind me saying so!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It's because I had to get up really early this morning.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh dear! What time did you have to get up?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Eight o'clock.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oh, Neil! That isn't early! I get up at six every day. It's so peaceful early in the morning.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hmm. Well, some people are morning people and others… aren't!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. Well, today we're talking about the biological reason for this – it's all about circadian rhythms . They are produced by a so-called body clock in our brains that regulates our body functions: our body temperature, sleepiness and alertness, hunger, and hormone levels. Plants, animals, and many microbes have circadian rhythms.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You know a lot about circadian rhythms.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And I'll ask you a question related to them. What does the word 'circadian' mean? Is it… a) around a day? b) every day? or c) twice a day?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hmm. I'm going to say a) around a day.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out whether you got the answer right or not later on in the show. Now let's talk about circadian rhythms and our internal clock.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Why do our bodies need an internal clock to tell us where we are in the day? Isn't it obvious?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, it isn't – take jet lag, for example. We rely on the predictable cycle of light or dark in a 24-hour period to synchronise – or adjust – our body clocks to the environment – and if we mess about with the light and dark cycle by flying into a new time zone, it makes us feel really bad!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Good point – jet lag is the disruption of our circadian rhythms caused by high-speed travel across different time zones, which can cause tiredness and sleep problems. But Alice, if we rely on day turning to night to adjust our body clocks, what happens to blind people? – Because I assume their body clocks can't do this.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Blind people who have some light perception are able to synchronise their circadian rhythms to the light-dark cycle. But those who have no light perception at all… well, let's listen now to Debra Skene, Professor of Neuroendocrinology at the University of Surrey. She can explain what happens.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Debra Skene, Professor of Neuroendocrinology at the University of Surrey Totally blind people – they've lost that connection between the light-dark circle and the clock. So there isn't anything wrong with the clock but the clock ticks and oscillates at its own endogenous period just the same as if I were to put you in a dark cave. Your biological internal clock would oscillate at your endogenous circadian period.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So if you're totally blind – or able to see but living in a dark cave – you have a ticking clock but with no connection to the outside world. The clock oscillates at its own endogenous , or internal, period.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Oscillate means to move back and forth in a regular rhythm – like the pendulum on a clock.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Do you think my endogenous clock ticks faster than yours, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It isn't a competition, Neil. And actually, mine probably ticks faster than yours since I'm a morning person. Anyway, the normal range in humans is between 23.8 to 24.8 hours. And this is also true for totally blind people.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But their clocks are free-running – they don't get cues from the outside environment telling them when to wake up, when to eat, when to feel sleepy. So that means they might feel sleepy at the wrong time of day – for example, when they're at work. Or alert in the middle of the night when they should be asleep.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It's worth talking about people who do shift work too – which means work that takes place outside the traditional 9 to 5 day.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Shift workers may suffer similar problems to blind people because they are trying to sleep against the clock. They might sleep in the day and work at night for example – which goes against the light-dark pattern.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: There are some long-term health problems associated with shift work – certain cancers, heart disease, and obesity.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So what can people do to help adapt their circadian rhythms to a night shift schedule?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, let's hear what Professor Debra Skene has to say about it.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Debra Skene, Professor of Neuroendocrinology at the University of Surrey We do think that exercise and food, caffeine, may be able to modulate in some way, so has some influence on circadian timing, but not as strongly as the light-dark cycle.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So the strongest influence over our circadian rhythm is the light-dark cycle. We can't alter night and day, after all!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Debra Skene says that other cues such as food and exercise will modulate – or adjust – the body clock. So eating three well-balanced meals at regular times each day can help your body clock adapt to an unusual schedule.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Taking naps – or short sleeps – just before you start a night shift can help you feel more alert. And keeping to the same sleep schedule every day will also help.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And don't forget caffeine – my old friend! A cup of coffee works wonders for me in the morning. Now remember I asked: What does 'circadian' mean? Is it… a) around a day, b) every day or c) twice a day?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said around a day.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And you were… right! Well done, Neil. The term 'circadian' comes from the Latin circa , meaning 'around' (or 'approximately'), and di ē m , meaning 'day'. Now, let's hear the words we learned today.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: They are: circadian rhythms synchronise jet lag oscillate endogenous shift work modulate naps

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: That's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Don't forget to join us again soon!

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
